title: Development of Nursing
description: The aim of this course is to enable students to develop their understanding of the evolution and development of nursing. In particular, it focuses on the development of the philosophy and knowledge base in nursing. Reference to systematic methods of providing humanistic care within the health care delivery systems will be made.
outcome: 1. Discuss the historical development and evolution of nursing.  2. Describe the philosophy of nursing.  3. Discuss the concepts and determinants of health and illness.  4. Describe the health care delivery systems.  5. Discuss the major components of nursing process and its utilization in nursing care.
syllabus: The Nursing Profession:  History of nursing Definition of nursing Philosophy of nursing Four major concepts in nursing Nursing theories and models Roles of the nurse Nursing care plan and nursing diagnosis  Concepts of Health and Health Care Delivery Systems:  Concepts of health and illness Factors influencing health Health care delivery systems, local and world-wide Primary health care  Nursing Process - A Problem-Solving Approach in Nursing:  Assessment: comprehensive health assessment of individuals, family, and community Planning Implementation Evaluation
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing I
description: This course aims to equip students with the foundational knowledge and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students’ understanding of the application of basic nursing care principles to safely help clients to meet their basic needs of living. Occupational health and infection control will also be included.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Develop basic communication skills. 2. Apply therapeutic and effective communication skills to care for individuals.  3. Understand principles and knowledge underlying the performance of essential nursing skills.  4. Demonstrate proficiency in nursing skills that meets the client basic living needs. 5. Demonstrate the ability to report and document all nursing actions and care delivered.
syllabus: Communication, interviewing and counseling: Communication theories and application, effective communication and interpersonal relationship, communication with health care team and consumers, skills of negotiation, lobbying, interviewing and counselling.  Essential nursing techniques: Ensuring a safe and comfortable environment for care, maintenance and promotion of occupational safety and health, documenting and reporting of care.  Assisting clients to meet basic needs of living: Meeting safety needs, meeting psychosocial needs, maintaining body temperature, promoting hygiene, promoting rest and sleep, facilitating relief from pain, loss and grief, death and dying.  Wound dressing: Pathophysiology of wounds and wound healing, wound assessment and classification, impact of acute and chronic wounds, principles of wound management and wound dressing procedures.  Skills: - Basic communication skills - Initial interview and health history taking - General head to toe observations - Measuring and assessing vital signs - Bedmaking - Oral and personal hygiene - Infection control - Simple wound dressing (wound swab, dressing materials) - Complicated wound care (drain, packing irrigation, sutures, clips) - Pain control (patient control analgesia, hot and cold therapy) - General procedures (admission, transfer and discharge clients, documenting and reporting)
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing II
description: This course aims to further equip students with the foundational knowledge and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students’ understanding of the application of basic nursing care principles to safely help clients to meet their basic needs of living. Intravenous therapy and care will also be included.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Understand basic concepts of nutrition and dietetics.  2. Describe nursing responsibilities in preparing and assisting the client to undertake diagnostic procedures.  3. Discuss principles and knowledge underlying the performance of essential nursing skills.  4. Apply the knowledge and problem solving skills to the care of clients with mobility and nutritional needs.  5. Apply the knowledge and problem solving skills to the promotion of sexual health, spiritual health 6. Demonstrate proficiency in nursing skills to meet the needs of clients receiving peripheral intravenous injection and infusion.
syllabus: Major concepts and topics to be covered: 1. Activity and mobility - Principles of care for immobility and bed confinement. - Pressure sore assessment and prevention. - Care of the ambulant client and use of ambulatory devices. - Principles and techniques of moving and lifting. - Principles of physiotherapy and occupational therapy. 2. Nutrition and dietetics - Basic concepts about food and nutrients. - A balanced diet for growth and optimal health.  - Introduction of therapeutic diets.  - Industrialization , urbanization and changes in food habits. - Economics in the choice of food, hospital diet. 3. Fluid and nutrition - Measures to promote a person’s nutritional status, dietary and fluid intake, intake and output record. - Assessing nutritional needs associated with each stage of the life cycle. - Factors that influence fluid and nutritional balance, signs of feeding problems. - Preparing and serving food, feeding technique. - Enteral / tube feeding.  4. Diagnostic procedures - Imaging procedures including various types of x-ray examinations, ultrasonography, magnetic resonance imaging and pulmonary function studies. - Endoscopic examinations. - Diagnostic procedures for laboratory studies including tissue biopsies, lumbar puncture, aspirations of cavities, endocrine activity tests and collection of specimens. - Electrographic diagnostic studies including electrocardiogram, electroencephalogram and electromyogram.  5. Promoting sexual health - Sexuality and client’s health status - Principles of performing breast self-examination (BSE) and testicular self-examination (TSE) 6. Promoting spiritual health - Concepts of spirituality and spiritual care - Assessing spiritual needs - Nurses’ role in spiritual care 7. Nursing skills - Prevention, assessment and treatment of pressure sores. - Range of motion exercise, use of restraints. - Assisting a client to walk with/ without ambulatory devices. - Positioning and transfer. - Specimen collection including vomit, gastric aspirate, blood glucose and cholesterol. - Assisting diagnostic procedures including abdominal paracentesis, thoracentesis, bone marrow biopsy, liver biopsy and renal biopsy. - Feeding dependent clients, screen for swallowing difficulties. - Intake and output, dietary record. - Nasogastric tube insertion and withdrawal. - Administering feeding via nasogastric tube, gastrostomy and jejunostomy tube.  - Introducing intravenous (IV) therapy: - Initiating peripheral IV infusion  - Regulating IV flow rate - Using volume control devices/infusion pumps  - Adding medication to IV bolus - Administrating IV bolus  - Irrigating a heparin lock - Basic principles of venipuncture and blood taking - Breast self-examination - Testicular self-examination

title: Fundamentals of Nursing III
description: This course continuously further equips students with the foundational knowledge and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students’ understanding of the application of basic nursing care principles to safely help clients to meet their basic needs of living. Principles of first aid and drug administration will also be included.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Understand principles and knowledge underlying the performance of essential nursing skills. 2. Demonstrate the ability to perform nursing skills that meets the client’s basic living needs. 3. Understand principles and knowledge in first aid management. 4. Demonstrate proficiency in carrying out basic life support. 5. Demonstrate the ability to administer medications.
syllabus: Meeting bowel elimination needs: - normal bowel patterns, factors affecting bowel elimination and measures to maintain a regular pattern of bowel elimination; observation of stools and collection of specimens; assisting clients to use devices for bowel elimination (bedpans and commodes/sani-chairs); identifying and caring clients with bowel elimination problems (diarrhoea and bowel incontinence); nursing interventions in managing constipation, impaction and flatulence (inserting suppositories, giving enemas and rectal washouts).  - Related nursing skills: giving and removing bedpan/urinal, assisting clients to use lavatory/commode/sani-chairs, observation and collection of faeces, inserting a rectal suppository and administering an enema, changing napkin on adult clients.  Meeting urinary elimination needs: - factors affecting urinary elimination; problems with urinary elimination; collection of urine specimens and urinalysis with reference to characteristics of urine; care of clients with urinary incontinence and measures to promote continence; care of clients with altered urinary elimination (retention and incontinence) - catheterization and bladder drainage.  - Related nursing skills: Urine testing (glucose, protein, ketones, SG, pH, occult blood), applying a condom drainage system, inserting and removing indwelling/straight catheters for males and females, collecting mid stream urine and catheterized urine specimen.  First Aid: - Introduction: aims and management principles, casualty assessment, methods of transferring and carrying injured persons, the use of different types of bandage and splints, improvisation of equipment and utilization of available materials.  - First aid management of various conditions: trauma care (wounds, haemorrhage, and shock); burns and scalds; heat/cold injuries; musculoskeletal injuries (sprains, strains, dislocations, and fractures); loss of consciousness, fits and convulsions; bites and stings; foreign bodies; choking, asphyxia, drowning, and poisoning.  Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (basic life support for adults). - Related nursing skills: basic bandaging, managing bleeding, shock, burns, heat & cold emergencies, water emergencies, poisoning emergencies, bites & stings, musculoskeletal injuries, removing foreign body causing airway obstruction, adult cardiopulmonary resuscitation.  Administration of medications: - principles of medication administration; basic written language and mathematical processes in drug therapy; routes, methods and techniques; rules and safety measures; ordering, storage, custody, and recording of controlled drugs according to related drug control ordinances; responsibilities of nurses in relation to medications, the rights and responsibilities of clients in relation to taking medications.  - Related nursing skills: administering oral medications, preparing an injectable medication from an ampoule or vial, administering intradermal, subcutaneous, and intramuscular injections, administering topical applications (skin, eye, nasal, ear), administering ophthalmic instillation, care and custody of drugs: storing, checking, recording, and ordering.
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

title: Clinical Practice I
components:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
description: This first clinical course aims to help students to understand nursing through experiential learning. Main emphasis would be on orientating them to the community and hospital environments, introducing the roles of nurses and other health-care team members, and familiarizing them with the existing health-care model and systems. Besides, students will be further provided clinical practice opportunities to apply and consolidate the knowledge and skills on interpersonal communication, health assessment and basic nursing skills for promoting clients’ health and wellness.

title: Anatomy
description: The course aims to provide students with basic knowledge of human topographical anatomy with particular emphasis on those aspects of special significance in nursing practice. The course will run concurrently with Physiology (NURS1603) and the syllabus will be integrated so that students will be able to correlate structure and function.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Familiarize with the general organization of the organs in the body and how they organize to form a functional system. 2. Learn the importance of the structural relationship and arrangement in the clinical setting. 3. Describe both the macroscopic and microscopic structures of the organs, and relate them to the functions of the organs. 4. Learn the origin and development of the organs and the associated birth defects.
syllabus: 1. Cell and Tissues2. Cardiovascular Systems (heart, artery, vein) 3. Clinical Anatomy (cardiovascular system, skin, respiratory system, musculoskeletal system, digestive system, urinary system, endocrine system, reproductive system, nervous system) 4. Blood and Skin 5. Respiratory, musculoskeletal, digestive, urinary, endocrine and reproductive systems, and nervous system (telencephalon, brainstem and cerebellum, cranial nerves, autonomic, pathway and special senses)
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Physiology
description: The course aims to enhance students’ knowledge and understanding of how the body adapts physiologically to internal and external environmental changes. It focuses on the physiological principles of normal cells, tissue and system functioning which will form the basis for studying health promotion, pathology and nursing care. The course content will be integrated with that offered in Anatomy (NURS1403).
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Describe the action potential of a neuron and understand the physiological role of nerve impulse conduction. 2. Explain how a skeletal muscle contracts and how muscle fatigue is formed. 3. Describe and explain how homeostasis maintains physiological function. 4. Explain how the cardiovascular system regulates the blood flowing through the tissues. 5. Explain how some of the altered functions in the cardiovascular and pulmonary systems. kidneys, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and central nervous system affect the body. 6. Describe the roles of blood in haemostasis and immune defense. 7. Explain how the pulmonary system and the blood transport oxygen to and carbon dioxide from tissues. 8. Describe the processes by how the kidneys regulate the body fluid volume and its composition. 9. Understand how the gastrointestinal system carries out the digestion and absorption of ingested food. 10. Summarize the roles of various hormones and understand the mechanisms of their secretions. 11. Recall the structure of the nervous system and understand how autonomic nervous system affects body functions. 12. Explain how the special senses particularly the eyes and ears function in human. 13. Summarize the general principles on how the tissues and organs work altogether to maintain homeostasis.
syllabus: 1. General Physiology 2. Cardiovascular system 3. Hematology 4. Respiration 5. Body Fluid Compartments 6. Renal Physiology 7. Acid Base Physiology 8. Neurophysiology 9. Gastrointestinal Physiology 10. Endocrinology 11. Reproduction
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Microbiology
description: The course aims to help students to acquire basic understanding of microbiology. Emphasis will be placed on micro-organisms that are commonly found on humans and those that are potentially pathogenic. Preventive and control measures in the hospital will also be introduced.
outcome: 1. Demonstrate a basic understanding of micro-organisms that are potentially pathogenic to human. 2. Demonstrate the basic concept of infection control. 3. Demonstrate the ability to use Personal Protective Equipment appropriately.
syllabus: Area 1 : Basic Infection Control Module Content: - Breaking the chain of transmission; - Principles of Hospital Infection and its Control; - Reducing the infective source & reservoir; - Immunization & Prophylaxis; - Management of Needleprick injury;  - Special issues on SARS and influenza.  Skills:  - Hand hygiene technique - Use of Personal Protective Equipment   Area 2 : Basic Microbiology  - Basic Morphology and Physiology - Gram positive bacteria, Gram Negative Bacteria, Anaerobes - Mycobacteria - Fungi - Parasites - Other Organisms - Virology - Normal Flora - Principles of Epidemiology - Control of Hospital Infection in Special settings - Pathogenesis of bacterial infections
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Infectious Diseases and Their Control
description: The course aims to help students to understand clinical infectious diseases and their control. Emphasis will be placed on clinical and nursing aspects including principles of diagnosis and treatment, epidemiology and prevention strategies, methods of surveillance, development of policies on infection control and the clinical impact of infection control teams in the hospital and community.

title: Disaster Nursing
description: This elective course aims to introduce students to the concepts of nursing dealing with disasters, disaster preparedness, nursing activities during and after disaster, and rebuilding the communities after disaster. Emphasis will be on the assessment and care at time of disaster, especially for vulnerable groups such as the elderly, mentally ill, pregnant women and children.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. Apply principles of disaster nursing care to clients during and after disaster. 2. Demonstrate the ability to perform physical, psychological and social care to clients (individuals, families, communities) during disaster. 3. Demonstrate the ability to perform physical, psychological and social care to clients (individuals, families, communities) in post-disaster period. 4. Formulate care to meet the needs of vulnerable populations such as children, disabled and elderly persons after disaster. 5. Integrate legal and ethical concerns in post disaster nursing. 6. Analyse the needs and plan the care for the disaster carers.
syllabus: • The nature of disasters • Disaster preparation and response system • Disaster field management  • Chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear disasters • Psychosocial impact of disasters and their management • Special populations in disasters • Public health issues under disaster conditions • Disaster resilience • Legal and ethical issues in disaster • Directions for nursing education, research & development
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Culture and Nursing
description: This course aims to facilitate students' understanding of the theories and concepts about culture that are relevant to nursing and enable them to provide person-centred care in a multicultural healthcare context.

title: Application of Public Health and Epidemiology in Nursing
description: This course aims to develop students' ability to understand the principles and theories of public health and epidemiology. Emphasis will be on the application of these principles and theories in nursing practice to promote population health.

title: The Hong Kong Health Care System
description: The aims of this course are to develop students' ability to understand and analyse the health care system in Hong Kong, with emphasis on structures, policies, and contemporary issues underpinning the provision of health care. Shifts in the organisation of health care provision and their implications for nursing practice will be examined.

title: Scholarly Inquiries in Nursing
description: This course provides students the opportunity to design a scholarly inquiry or project such as concept analysis, literature review or a proposal on a specific nursing or health-related problem. Students will select a topic of interest to them under the supervision of a faculty member. Through the learning process, students will deepen knowledge and techniques in scholarly project and nursing research.

title: Student Exchange Programme
description: This course aims to provide exchange opportunities and experiences for students to learn about nursing and health care systems in mainland China and other countries. This course will also provide valuable cross-cultural insights to enhancing students' understanding of the diverging approaches to nursing education and practice.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students should be able to  1. Deepen their understanding of the nursing education system and the delivery of health care services in Mainland China and/or other countries. 2. Broaden their vision and knowledge of the current nursing practice with students from Mainland China and/or other countries. 3. Discuss relevant cultural differences in the delivery of health care services. 4. Demonstrate reflective and critical thinking abilities in comparing two different health care systems.
syllabus: List of Topics: Healthcare system and nursing education in Hong Kong Healthcare systems and nursing education in the different countries Reflective journal writing
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Traditional Chinese Medicine Nursing
description: This course aims to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and TCM nursing, with a focus on the development of TCM nursing knowledge and skills for therapeutic nursing interventions and clinical decision making. It also aims to develop students’ competence in evidence-based practice and outcome evaluation in TCM nursing.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Demonstrate an understanding of the health concepts of TCM. 2. Understand the basics of Chinese herbal medicine.  3. Identify the scope and principles of TCM nursing. 4. Apply TCM nursing principles and skills in health assessment and patient care planning 5. Apply evidence-based knowledge to inform TCM nursing practice. 6. Demonstrate professional nursing roles in coordinating TCM nursing care for clients with the interdisciplinary health care team.
syllabus: (1) Concepts and theories of TCM  Fundamentals of TCM   Traditional theory and scientific foundation and evidence of acupuncture (2) Theoretical principles of TCM nursing and their applications  Therapeutic principles of TCM nursing   TCM application in nursing practice   Exploring TCM practices in nursing research  (3) TCM dialectical nursing  TCM acupuncture and tuina nursing   TCM medical and surgical nursing   TCM nursing care of common diseases
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

title: Fundamentals of Genetic and Genomic Nursing
description: This course aims to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of genetic and genomic nursing and equip them with essential knowledge and competencies to provide genetic counselling to individuals and families affected by or at risk of genetic disorders.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts in genetics and genomics. Understand the essentials of genetic and genomic nursing. Identify the scope of nursing practice in genetics and genomics. Apply nursing skills in genetic assessment and counselling for individuals and families who are at risk or at higher risk of genetic disorders. Demonstrate professional nursing roles by effectively collaborating with health care team members from different disciplines, including doctors, laboratory specialists, medical social workers and clinical psychologists.
syllabus: Foundation in genetics Genetic assessment Genetic testing for genetic disorders Genetic counselling
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

William M W Mong Eng Bldg 703

William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408

title: Complementary and Alternative Medicine
description: The aim of this course is to introduce students to the efficacy, choice, and explanatory mechanisms of complementary and alternative medicine using a range of selected therapies. A regional focus will be on the health concepts and common approaches of Chinese medicine. The roles and responsibilities of nurses within this field are discussed.
outcome: 1. Demonstrate an understanding of the underlying concepts of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM). 2. Recognize the integration of Chinese medicine into the health care system of Hong Kong. 3. Determine the roles and responsibilities of nurses in complementary and alternative medicine. 4. Interpret the theories of Chinese Medicine (CM), such as Yin-Yang, the Five Elements, Zang-Fu, Meridians, etc. 5. Describe the special features of diagnosis and treatment in CM. 6. Demonstrate an understanding of dietary therapy from the perspectives of CM. 7. Analyze the major concepts, limitations and special precautions related to a variety of complementary and alternative therapies, including: CM therapies (e.g. acupuncture, moxibustion, tuina, cupping, guasha, bonesetting), homeopathy, aromatherapy, naturopathy, music therapy, therapeutic touch, hypnosis, and chiropractic. 8. Determine the relationship between homuncular reflex theory and its illustration in a number of therapies, including reflexology, auriculotherapy, and iridology. 9. Develop an awareness of certain exercising therapies in Chinese medicine, including: qigong and tai chi. 10. Recognize the role of complementary and alternative medicine as an integrated treatment approach with orthodox Western medicine.
syllabus: - Introduction to complementary & alternative medicine - The integration of Chinese medicine into the health care system of Hong Kong - Roles & responsibilities of nurses in CAM - Introduction to Chinese medicine (Part 1): health concepts of Chinese medicine, five elements theory, internal organs, functions and meridians - Introduction to Chinese medicine (Part 2): diagnosis and treatment in TCM; principles of dietary therapy - Acupuncture, moxibustion, tuina, cupping, guasha, bonesetting - Qigong, tai chi & therapeutic touch; Auricular therapy - Homeopathy; Reflexology - Aromatherapy; Naturopathy; Hypnosis; Iridology; Chiropractic; Music therapy - TCM clinic visit.
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Health Promotion
description: The aim of this course is to develop students' understanding of the role of the nurse in health promotion by working with individuals, groups, families and communities. Emphasis will be on the application of the principles of health promotion to critique programmes relevant to local current and predicted health needs.
outcome: 1. Examine the role of the nurse in undertaking health promotion with individuals, groups, families and communities. 2. Analyse current theories and models of health education and health promotion and their values in the delivery of such programmes. 3. Examine the contribution of health education to health promotion. 4. Analyse the changing pattern of community health and identify priorities and opportunities for health promotion. 5. Assess the learning needs of individuals, families, groups and communities. 6. Apply principles of health promotion to the implementation of programmes. 7. Evaluate the process and outcome of health promotion programmes for both the nurses and clients.
syllabus: Evolution of health education and health promotion, changing pattern of community health, models of health education and health promotion, contribution of health education to health promotion, the role of nursing in health promotion, principles of learning and teaching, factors influencing learning, assessing learning needs and planning activities, strategies for health education, evaluation of health education, screening and health protection, health promotion campaign and health promotion policies.
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 713

title: Introduction to Behavioural and Social Sciences
description: This course aims to provide students with the basic understanding of the concepts and theoretical approaches of sociology and psychology relevant to nursing and health care. Emphasis will be on the use of these concepts to understand individual and group behaviour and their health needs.
outcome: 1. Examine different approaches to the study of human behavior and their relevance to nursing and/ or health care.  2. Discuss psychosocial needs of individuals at different developmental stages across the lifespan.  3. Discuss the influence of motivation, emotion and individual differences on human behavior.  4. Examine the nature and structure of social groups within the context of Hong Kong such as gender, family, religion, class and work.  5. Discuss the influence of culture, social class, social change, power and politics in relation to the Hong Kong Chinese population.
syllabus: - Course introduction - Introducing sociological perspectives  - Introduction to psychology - Individual and society  - Emotion and Motivation - Social inequalities  - Psychological development and maturation - Basic concepts of psychosocial needs and potentialities of people throughout the life span - Social institutions I - Learning  - Social institutions II - Deviance  - Social change  - Memory - Personality  - Gender and sex-typing
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804

title: Trends and Professional Issues in Nursing
description: This course will enable students to integrate their knowledge and skills about professional issues into comprehensive understanding of health care. Students will be introduced to health care policy issues and operations of the health care system to further their understanding of health services development. This course introduces students to professionalism, political participation and evidence-based nursing. In addition, the course will prepare students for the use of information technology in the processing of information for nursing practice, research and education.
outcome: 1. Examine the factors influencing the future directions of nursing practice. 2. Explain the methods for assuring quality in health care by nurses and the health care team. 3. Compare and contrast different approaches to career ladders in nursing. 4. Examine the challenges in professional development of nursing in Hong Kong. 5. Compare and contrast different health system models. 6. Analyse the challenges of reforming Hong Kong’s health system. 7. Discuss nurses as agents of quality improvement. 8. Analyse the advantages and limitations of using computer applications in the management of information. 9. Examine the implications of information technology for practice, research and education. 10. Determine and apply the ethical and legal principles in the use of information technology.
syllabus: 1. Nursing practice and professional issues: Future directions, evidence-based nursing practice, expanded and extended roles of the nurse; clinical career ladders, specialization, advanced nursing practice, nursing audits, continuous quality improvement, professional socialization, level of nursing, preparation for professional nursing roles, professional organizations.  2. Nursing education issues: Basic nursing education and advanced education for nurses; competency-based education; preparation for specialty and advanced nursing practice, continuing nursing education.  3. Health care policy: Changing health care context and trends, health care reform, health care economics, health-care delivery models, the organization and management of health care, political participation, advocacy in nursing, participation in health care policy, nursing workforce issues.  4. Health and nursing informatics: Computer-aided learning, telehealth, systems available for hospital information, quality assurance, client assessment and monitoring, safety and security of information systems, protection of personal data, ethical and legal considerations in the use of information technology.
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 406
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 406

title: Nursing Research
description: This course helps students to understand the principles of nursing research and equip their knowledge of evidence based nursing. Emphasis will be given to introducing students to the use of qualitative and quantitative research methods, research design and research questions in practice to enable students to carry out a critical review of the literature in a particular area of clinical practice.
outcome: At the end of this course, students will be able to:  1. Discuss the contribution of nursing research to the development of evidence-based practice. 2. Differentiate the major assumptions, characteristics and approaches between the positivist and naturalist paradigms in developing nursing science.  3. Develop a workable research problem in a selected area of clinical practice.  4. Discuss the purposes and methods of conducting literature review for quantitative and qualitative researches. 5. Discuss the characteristics, applications, strengths and weakness of various study design for quantitative and qualitative researches.  6. Discuss the characteristics, applications, strengths and weakness of various sampling methods and approaches for data collection in quantitative and qualitative researches.  7. Understand the principles and applications of quantitative and qualitative data analyses.  8. Discuss the ethical implications of conducting research in clinical practice settings. 9. Critically appraise a research article in a selected area of clinical practice. 10. Evaluate the significance of a research study in advancing nursing practice. 11. Describe the concepts and principles of integrating participatory approach in nursing research and discuss its value-adding potential in promoting evidence-based nursing practice.
syllabus: Evidence-based practice in nursing profession & overview of the research process: Overview of the role of evidence-based practice in nursing; Two key methodological perspectives in nursing science; The major steps in a quantitative and qualitative studies; The similarities & differences on the research process of quantitative and qualitative study.  Research problems, research questions & hypothesis: The process of developing a research problem; The different purposes and characteristics of problem statements, statement of purpose, research questions and research hypotheses; Formulation of research questions and research hypothesis from problem statement and statement of purpose.  Searching and reviewing the literature: The purpose of a literature review; The appropriate information to include in a review of the literature; The methods of writing a literature review and of searching for existing literature for a research problem; The process of writing a literature review; Evaluation for the adequacy and quality of a literature review.  Quantitative research: study designs and issues of validity: The different types of experimental, quasi-experimental and non-experimental study designs, and their key characteristics; The purposes, strengths and weakness of each type study designs; The application of each type study designs in nursing research; Internal and external validity related to study design;   Quantitative research: sampling designs: Definitions of a population and a sample; The considerations in setting eligibility criteria; The rationales for sampling in research studies; The advantages and disadvantages of various sampling methods; The general considerations in estimating sample size in quantitative study; Evaluation for the sample method in a research study.  Quantitative research: data collection method: Overview of different formats of question and scaling techniques; The use of observational methods and biophysiological measures in collecting data for quantitative research; Levels of measurement among quantitative data.  Quantitative research: issues of reliability & validity on data collection: Overview of the major sources of measurement error; Concepts and dimensions of validity and reliability; Methods for evaluating reliability and validity.  Quantitative research: data analysis: Overview of using descriptive statistics in nursing research; The basic idea of hypothesis testing and the logic of tests of statistical significance; The general principles in identifying a statistical test for research hypothesis; Type I and Type II errors and their roles in hypothesis testing; Methods of data coding and data entry in quantitative studies.  Ethical issues in research: Overview of ethical issues in conducting a research; Main requirements for ethical approval.  Qualitative research: design & approach - Introduction to participatory action research in health care: The purposes and methods of different types of qualitative research design; Application of qualitative research in nursing research. Introduction to participatory action research in health care.  Qualitative research: sampling designs & data collection method: The importance of sampling; The criteria for judging the appropriateness and adequacy of sampling; Different methods of sampling; Issues in the sampling process.  Qualitative research: data analysis and issues of validity and reliability: Common data analysis strategies used in qualitative research; Specific data analysis procedures used in qualitative approaches; Issues of validity and reliability in qualitative research.
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Application of Behavioural and Social Sciences in Nursing
description: This course aims to draw upon the foundations of psychological and sociological concepts from a health and illness perspective, which is applicable to nursing practice in Hong Kong. With these concepts, students will examine the psychological and social determinants, which can be used to promote health, prevent illness and facilitate nursing interventions for individuals and families.
outcome: 1. Discuss the influence of health beliefs on people’s practice of health-related behaviour. 2. Analyze the impact of illness and hospitalization on individuals, their family and society. 3. Analyze the application of health psychology to health promotion and disease prevention. 4. Critically debate the main issues in the social organizations of health care. 5. Examine the social and cultural explanations of health and illness in relation to dimensions of social inequality including gender, ethnicity and class. 6. Compare and contrast professional and lay response to the understanding of health and illness.
syllabus: - Course introduction - Psychology of communication - Interpersonal relationship and conflict resolution for nursing students - Sociology for nurses – basic concepts and theories - Health Psychology - Social structure, culture, and health - Stress and coping - Political economy of health Stigmatization and patient care - Brain and behaviour - Social diversities in health  - Gendered perspectives in nursing care - Nursing and profession - Clinical Psychology - Psychological aspects of pain and nursing interventions - Psychological interventions for surgery and recovery
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Nursing in the Community
description: This course aims to provide a theoretical foundation to community-based nursing and gerontology nursing. Emphasis will be placed on home-based assessment and management of common health problems in various community settings. This course enables students to formulate appropriate nursing care plan and apply evidence-based nursing interventions to community nursing and to the care of older people. Basic concepts of public health, epidemiology and fundamental pharmacology will be included.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Apply basic principles of community nursing and home-based nursing in the discussion of the specific conditions in the community. 2. Demonstrate the ability to systematically identify and analyse the scope for gerontological care for the promotion of the health and wellness of older people in various settings. 3. Understand the basic concepts of public health and epidemiology.  4. Describe principles of basic pharmacological nursing.
syllabus: Major concepts and topics to be covered:  Community nursing:  Principles of community nursing Development and trends of community nursing in Hong Kong  Roles and responsibilities of the community nurse Common problems and management skill of community nursing  Planning and preparing for home visits Basic concepts of public health and epidemiology Family-centered care and community care Family/home-based assessment and care planning  Home care nursing and managing specific conditions at home Client and family education in home settings  Emotional problems and stress in the home Prevention and management of violence and aggression in the community  Community and social support for older adults Coordinating medical, health and social services to meet the clients & families needs  Community support and network for client in the community   Gerontological nursing: Epidemiology of aging Pathophysiology ,theories of aging and the normal aging process,  Philosophy of gerontological nursing and scope of care Comprehensive health assessment in older people_Functional assessment  Cognitive & neurosensory assessment in older adult  Cognitive function disorder: confusion, dementia  Common physical, and mental health problems and their management of older adults  Meeting physical needs and psychosocial needs of older people Addressing psychological problem & stress for older adults Homecare nursing & managing specific condition for older people (under nutrition, confusion, AOM consideration)  Mobility problem in older adult & fall prevention  Prevention of incontinence.  Geriatric rehabilitation Inter-disciplinary approach in the care of older people Health, social and residential care services for older people  Legal and ethical implications in gerontological care  End of life issues  Care plan in Community & Gerontological nursing:  Reinforce nursing care plan & nursing diagnosis in community nursing & gerontological nursing   Fundamental pharmacology: basic concepts of pharmacokinetics. major drug classifications and drug effects. forms of medication and client care applications. safety in drug therapy and clients care. the related laws and ordinances.  Skills: Cognitive & neurosensory assessment Bags technique in community nursing

title: Nursing in the Hospital I
description: This course provides the theoretical basis for comprehensive nursing care to clients in the hospital with mild to moderate health problems. The pathophysiological basis and pharmacological treatment of medical-surgical nursing conditions will be examined together with the principles of therapeutic management and nursing therapeutics skills. Students will learn to assess, plan and implement appropriate evidence-based nursing interventions to reduce or overcome the effects of these conditions.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Formulate a nursing care plan appropriate to the health condition identified in the nursing assessment process. 2. Demonstrate ability to perform nursing skills safely and efficiently in the laboratory and clinical settings. 3. Develop an awareness of using established outcome measures to assess and document the effects of nursing interventions. 4. Explain the biopsychosocial dimensions of nursing practice, including the pathophysiological basis and body adaptation to the disease process, client education and psychosocial support to clients and family. 5. Apply the basic principles of pharmacological interventions in clinical nursing practice. 6. Apply principles and research findings from the biological, behavioural and nursing sciences in the care of clients with:  - Respiratory disorders  - Oesophageal disorders  - Gastrointestinal disorders  - Gall bladder, pancreatic and hepatic disorders  - Pre- and post-operative care of common surgeries
syllabus: Application of nursing assessment tools in clinical practice: Identification of nursing problems through the use of nursing assessment tools Formulation of appropriate NANDA approved nursing diagnoses Formulation of realistic client-centred goals and measurable outcomes Planning and implementation of appropriate nursing interventions in accordance with established rationale  Nursing care of clients with common health problems in hospitals (to include pathophysiological changes and body adaptation and pharmacological interventions): Respiratory disorders Gastrointestinal disorders Gall bladder disorders Pancreas disorders Hepatic disorders Enteric infections Surgical procedures  Nursing skills: Oxygen therapy, oropharyngeal and nasopharyngeal suctioning, steam inhalation and metered dose inhalers administration, airway insertion, breathing exercise and coughing exercises, tracheostomy care and suctioning, chest drain, pulmonary assessment, ambu-bag manual ventilator, artificial airway, non-invasive ventilation (BiPAP), mechanical ventilation, abdominal assessment, initiating and monitoring total parenteral nutrition (TPN) through central venous catheter, colostomy and ileostomy care.

title: Ethical and Legal Issues in Nursing
description: This course aims to develop students’ understanding of legal and ethical issues in relation to nursing. It focuses on the legal principles governing professional practice in Hong Kong including torts, contracts, confidentiality, informed consent and related ordinances; basic ethical principles and theories in relation to nursing practice; and ethical issues and dilemmas encountered in practice.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Recognise contemporary ethical issues in nursing practice. 2. Examine common ethical dilemmas within the context of nursing practice. 3. Identify different approaches to ethical decision-making. 4. Apply ethical principles and theories in analyzing the dilemmas. 5. Explain basic legal concepts and their relevance to nursing and health care. 6. Examine the principles of tort law and the Hong Kong Ordinances as related to nursing.
syllabus: Ethical aspects: - Bioethical principles and approaches and ethical decision-making models - Code of conduct, professional ethics and organizational constraints in nursing practice  Legal aspects: - The nature of law - The legal system in Hong Kong - Ordinances and principles of tort laws relevant to nursing; Negligence; Malpractice; Assault and battery; Informed consent; Defamation; Confidentiality; Documentation; Nurses Registration Ordinance; Pharmacy and Poison's Act; Dangerous Drug Act and Mental Health Ordinance. - Integrity in practice  Case studies: - Ethical and legal issues involved in truth telling, withholding and withdrawing treatment, euthanasia, abortion, organ transplant and research ethics

title: Nursing in Clinical Specialties I
description: This course aims to equip students with the knowledge and skills to care for clients with moderate to severe health problems. It focuses on physiological and/or pathophysiological changes, the application of nursing interventions, critical thinking, and research evidence to caring for clients in different clinical specialties.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Apply functional health pattern framework in studying physical and bio-psychosocial care of paediatric, adolescent and adult clients with alternations in medical/surgical conditions; 2. Perform comprehensive and focused health assessment of clients with altered functional patterns; 3. Critically analyze assessment data to diagnose acute and potential alternations in functional health patterns; 4. Apply principles and research evidence from biological, behavioural and nursing sciences in planning care for clients with:  - accident and emergency care;  - alternations in paediatric & adolescence health conditions; or  - alternations in eye, ear, nose and throat conditions 5. Integrate nursing care plan with psychosocial and cultural considerations; and 6. Apply psychosocial support and interventions in caring for clients and families experiencing moderate to severe health problems.
syllabus: Accident and Emergency Nursing: • Principles of Accident and Emergency Nursing • The roles and functions of emergency nurse • Triage system, triage nursing assessment and nursing care • Principles of managing client care in the emergency department • Nursing skills: triage nursing assessment  Paediatric & Adolescent Nursing • Theories of growth & development • Principles of paediatric & adolescent nursing • Health assessment in children & adolescents; Denver assessment • Paediatric & adolescent nutrition • Nursing care & management of infants & sick children • Nursing care & management of congenital disorders • Nursing care & management of health conditions in adolescents • Prevention of accidents at home & in hospital • Children's rights, child abuse & the related roles of the nurse • Play therapy • Nursing skills: paediatric and child CPR, collecting urine specimen, vital signs monitoring, applying restraints, blood exchange transfusion, lumber puncture, admission  Ophthalmic Nursing • Inflammatory and infective conditions, • Refractive errors • Retinal detachment • Cataract, glaucoma, squint & age-related macular degeneration • Eye injuries • Nursing skills: assessing visual acuity, removal of foreign body, eye irrigation  Oto-rhino-laryngological Nursing • Ear disorders: inflammatory and infective disorders, ear injuries, neoplasms, hearing impairment, Tinnitus, Ménière's disease, foreign bodies in ear • Nasal disorders: inflammatory and infective disorders (sinusitis, rhinitis), nasal injuries, foreign bodies in nostrils, epistaxis, neoplasms (nasal polyp, nasopharyngeal carcinoma) • Throat disorders: inflammation, foreign bodies in throat, neoplasms • Nursing skills: hearing assessment, balance tests, removal of foreign bodies, ear irrigation

Develop plans of care based on health assessment and principles supported by research. 3. Demonstrate competence in safe and efficient performance of nursing skills in various clinical specialties, and in the preparation and aftercare for investigative procedures. 4. Demonstrate effective communication with clients, their families, and health care team members. 5. Deepen critical decision-making skills in the provision of client-centered care. 6. Demonstrate the ability to communicate assessment, care planning, implementation and evaluation data by documentation. 7. Deepen the integration of the knowledge from applied behavioural and social science in the provision of client care. 8. Establish beginning ability to identify research topics from theoretical knowledge and practical experience. 9. Further develop critical thinking and clinical judgment from theoretical knowledge and practical experience.

title: Nursing Therapeutics
description: This course aims to extend students’ knowledge and essential nursing skills in promoting the health and wellness of clients. Students are enabled to apply basic principles of nursing care to safely help clients to meet their basic needs of living.

Apply the knowledge and problem solving skills to the care of clients with mobility and nutritional needs. 5. Demonstrate proficiency in nursing skills to meet the needs of clients receiving peripheral intravenous injection and infusion.

title: Coordinating Nursing Practice
description: This course will enable students to extend their theoretical and skill-based knowledge in co-coordinating individual client care and organising the care groups of clients in both hospital and community settings. Emphasis will be on leadership and management skills and the importance of multidisciplinary teamwork.
outcome: 1. Evaluate how the leadership skills of influencing; negotiating; decision making and team building can improve the quality of client care 2. Apply effective communication skills in the co-ordination of nursing practice. 3. Utilize available resources to maximize clients' outcomes. 4. Discuss strategies to manage conflict and/or manage complaints successfully. 5. Discuss strategies to manage crisis successfully. 6. Analyze theories of change and their implications for nursing practice. 7. Discuss the roles of client care manager and unit manager. 8. Develop the ability with professional development to contribute as citizens and leaders.
syllabus: Leadership in nursing and health care: Leadership theories, team building and group dynamics, motivation and influencing skills, problem solving and decision making skills  Management theories, skills and application: Theories and process of management, resource management, crisis management, quality management, change management  Student professional development: Mock interview and career development

title: Nursing for Complex Health Needs
description: This course aims to integrate practice with theory to understand the nature of caring for individuals across developmental stages that are at risk or who have complex health problems. The course helps students to explore factors contributing to the complexity of changes in health. The foci will be on the physiological and/or pathophysiological changes, the application of nursing interventions, critical thinking, and research evidence to caring for clients with different complex health needs.
outcome: In regard to the care of child, adult and elderly clients with complex health problems, students will be able to: 1. Apply a selected framework in studying the bio-psychosocial care of clients who have developed complex health problems across the life span.  2. Contrast between the health assessment and nursing care for patients across the life-span.  3. Conduct a critical analysis on assessment data to diagnose actual and potential alterations in functional health problems.  4. Design and implement a holistic, accurate and evidence-based nursing care plan at an individual and family level for patients with complex health needs.  5. Prioritize client care considering life threatening situations as well as client preference.
syllabus: Oncology and palliative nursing • Principles of oncology nursing. • Principles of radiation therapy and chemotherapy. • Care of clients undergoing radiation therapy and chemotherapy. • Occupational safety in radiation therapy and chemotherapy. • Pain and symptom management. • Principles of palliative care. • Legal and ethical issues.  Rehabilitative nursing • An overview of rehabilitative care: principles of rehabilitation, comprehensive assessment, family-centered care, roles and responsibilities of rehabilitative nurses.  • Principles and programs in cardiac rehabilitation, neurological rehabilitation, pulmonary rehabilitation, and geriatric rehabilitation. • Framework of care in cardiac rehabilitation, neurological rehabilitation, pulmonary rehabilitation and geriatric rehabilitation. • Principles of planning, implementing and evaluating nurse-led initiatives for patients with chronic illness.  Obstetric Nursing  • Principles of care in normal pregnancy, labour and puerperium. • Physiological and psychological changes in pregnancy.  • Common complications of pregnancy, labour and puerperium. • Newborn care (including neonates, preterm and small for dated babies), breastfeeding versus bottle-feeding. • Postpartum adaptation & family visit. • Introduction to obstetric emergencies.  • Roles and responsibilities of midwife.  Skills: • Antenatal assessment • Nursing interventions to promote comfort during child birth • Newborn care

title: Clinical Practice VI
components:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Laboratory
Lecture

description: This clinical practice course aims to provide opportunities for students to identify and analyse the effect of complex changes in health and the impact of multiple health agencies on clients. Students are expected to demonstrate competence in the delivery of holistic care for clients with complex health problems and to promote health across different age groups. Additionally, under the supervision of experienced nurses, students are required to demonstrate responsibility for their own decision making about nursing interventions, evaluating practice and managing care for a group of clients. Students are expected to work collaboratively with the health-care team in the delivery of care to clients.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Integrate knowledge and skills from nursing, biological, behavioural and social sciences in the provision of holistic nursing care for clients with complex health problems. 2. Demonstrate competence in promotion of health and delivery of holistic care of clients with complex health problems. 3. Demonstrate proficiency in using the nursing process as a problem-solving approach in the provision of client-centred care. 4. Demonstrate competence in family nursing for geriatric clients. 5. Integrate research evidence in the delivery of nursing care. 6. Demonstrate competence in organizational skills to co-ordinate the care of groups of clients and families. 7. Demonstrate effective communication with clients, their families, and health care team members. 8. Demonstrate competence in critical thinking and decision-making in the provision of client-centred care. 9. Demonstrate appropriate professional attitudes and relevant applications of ethical and legal principles in the practice of nursing. 10. Demonstrate competence in the safe and efficient performance nursing skills throughout clinical practice. 11. Demonstrate the proficiency in using reflective skills for self and peer appraisal of nursing care. 12. Demonstrate understanding of the importance of lifelong and ongoing professional development.
syllabus: Major concepts and topics to be covered: Medical Nursing/ Rehabilitation Nursing/ Oncology Nursing
required_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.
recommended_readings: Reading list as stated in course outline.

title: Nursing Research I
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This course is designed for research students to explore recent research developments in nursing in order to facilitate them to identify interesting and important research areas.
outcome: This course will enable students to: • Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance to the professional development in nursing.  • Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and professional issues in nursing. • Critically discuss and evaluate the methodological issues arising from the research presentation.  • Disseminate their research proposal and findings effectively, and demonstrate the techniques to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, results interpretation and discussions.  • Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.

title: Advancing Nursing Science I
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This research unit provides students with continuing supervision and monitoring of their progress in developing and writing up their theses.
outcome: The course will enable students to: 1. Analyse the implications of nursing knowledge for their chosen research topic; 2. Critically assess the contribution of the literature to their research study; 3. Analyse the appropriateness of different research designs to the context of the research study; 4. Justify the appropriateness of the sampling designs and methods selected for their research study; 5. Analyse and evaluate methods of data collection in the context of their research study; 6. Evaluate the contribution of different methods of data analysis to their research study; 7. Practise and evaluate a range of data collection and data analysis techniques; 8. Examine the processes of systematic reviews as the foundation for informed clinical practice. 9. Develop techniques to appraise, extract and pooling of data collected through the systematic review process. 10 Develop a proposal for their research study.

requirements: For students in Master of Nursing and Doctor of Nursing
description: This course aims to prepare students for competent delivery of nursing care and services in the designated nursing specialty, or assumption of nursing management roles in the complex healthcare environment. The course provides students with requisite specialty knowledge and skills for advanced care management and patient care, or advanced practice in management and leadership. In addition, the course develops students’ understanding of evidence-based concepts and ability to apply knowledge of evidence-based practice to enhance quality of healthcare services.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. apply essential knowledge and skills in the advanced nursing practice. 2. integrate assessment findings into planning of interventions for clients in advanced nursing practice.3. identify evidence-based interventions for advanced nursing practice. 4. deliver interventions to clients of the designated nursing specialty safely and effectively. 5. evaluate the effectiveness of existing interventions in advanced nursing practice. 6. apply knowledge of evidence-based practice to enhance quality of healthcare services.

requirements: For students in Master of Nursing and Doctor of Nursing
description: This course aims to prepare students for competent delivery of nursing care and services in the designated nursing specialty, or assumption of nursing management roles in the complex healthcare environment. The course provides students with requisite specialty knowledge and skills for advanced care management and patient care, or advanced practice in management and leadership. It also emphasises quality of care and safety in specialty nursing. In addition, the course strengthens students’ knowledge of nursing informatics and deepens their understanding of ethical and legal aspects in specialty nursing.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. apply advanced knowledge and skills in the designated nursing specialty/ healthcare management. 2. integrate assessment findings into planning of interventions for clients in advanced nursing practice.3. identify evidence-based interventions for advanced nursing practice. 4. deliver interventions to clients of the designated nursing specialty safely and effectively. 5. evaluate the effectiveness of existing interventions in advanced nursing practice. 6. discuss quality and safety issues in advanced nursing practice. 7. describe nursing informatics and use of information technology in health care. 8. discuss a range of ethical and legal issues in relation to professional practice.

title: Professional Skill Competency
components:
Discussion
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to build up students’ professional skill competency in advanced nursing practice. It is designed to enable students to apply the knowledge and skills they have learned in the previous courses in their specialty. The emphasis is on out-of-class professional learning experience and reflective learning of professional skills through regular interactions with clinical nursing experts in the designated nursing specialty. In addition, supplementary learning activities such as virtual reality laboratory practice, reflective reports, portfolios, and group discussions are used to enhance students’ mastery of the professional skills.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. apply the knowledge and skills of the designated nursing specialty in clinical practice. 2. reflect on personal mastery of professional skills in the designated nursing specialty. 3. discuss clinical cases as specialty nurses. 4. demonstrate professional skill competency in the designated nursing specialty.

title: Scholarly Inquiry I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to help students develop knowledge and skills to critically appraise literature resources with a focus on advanced nursing practice. This will involve analyzing the contribution of research and appropriateness of the research approaches to knowledge development.

title: Scholarly Inquiry II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course provides students with opportunities to broaden their knowledge on quantitative and qualitative research methodologies, service development, and analysis of healthcare provision. It enables students to develop a scholarly inquiry proposal and conduct a scholarly inquiry project.

title: Scholarly Inquiry
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills to critically appraise literature and summarise evidence to improve nursing practice and health outcomes of individuals and populations. This will involve analysing the contribution of research and the appropriateness of the research approaches to knowledge development.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. analyse the processes for establishing current evidence for specific areas of nursing practice.  2. identify the benefits and limitations of evidence-based practice.  3. critically review the literature that underlies a selected healthcare topic.  4. evaluate the designs and methods commonly used in research and service innovation project.  5. discuss the quality of measurement in both quantitative and qualitative research.  6. develop a critical review of the literature in a selected area of a nursing topic.

title: Contemporary Issues in Advanced Nursing Practice
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to enable students to expand knowledge and understanding of nursing practice in a diverse context. The course covers theoretical foundation of nursing practice, social determinants of health in relation to various populations including children, adolescents, older people and families, healthcare policy, healthcare financing, healthcare system organisation, human diversity and social issues that influence nursing practice. The course also enables students to discuss strategies, approaches and interventions to address the emerging health issues.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. examine the fundamental concepts, beliefs and values of nursing models in the context of contemporary healthcare environment.  2. describe health equity issues and specific health needs of different populations. 3. discuss the professional role of nurses and the scope of nursing practice in a diverse context. 4. critically appraise the recent healthcare policy initiatives, healthcare financing and healthcare system organisation, and their impacts on population health.  5. discuss strategies, approaches and interventions to health promotion, disease prevention and health restoration.

title: Advanced Health Assessment and Clinical Judgment
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing or Doctor of Nursing
description: This course provides students with opportunities to apply their knowledge and skills of comprehensive history taking and physical assessment to both healthcare and community settings, with emphasis on differentiation between normal and abnormal findings, identification of common health problems, process of critical thinking and clinical judgment through analysis of clinical findings.

title: Evidence-based Practice for Quality Care
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing or Doctor of Nursing
description: This course facilitates students to expand their scope of clinical practice by undertaking an in-depth examination of their specialty area of practice. Students are expected to further develop their skills in clinical decision-making and to promote evidence-based practice in their relevant clinical specialty.

title: Clinical Leadership, Management and Outcome Evaluation
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing or Doctor of Nursing
description: This course focuses on developing students' understanding of healthcare management, leadership and the process of health outcome evaluation. Related frameworks for healthcare management, continuous quality improvement and outcome evaluations will be explored to guide students in assuming a managerial role and making quality improvement decisions in their specialty practice.

title: Student-led Seminar I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This seminar aims to provide students with opportunities to present and share their scholarly inquiry project with their peers and the academic staff. It emphasizes on the critical review of the literature related to the project. In addition, reflection of the process of literature review and the strategies used to overcome difficulties during the development of the scholarly inquiry project will be shared and discussed.

title: Student-led Seminar II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This seminar aims to provide students with opportunities to present and share with their peers and the academic staff about the research method or project plan of their scholarly inquiry project. In addition, reflection of the development process of research method or project plan and the strategies used to overcome difficulties during the process will be shared and discussed.

title: Advanced Biostatistics in Evidence-based Practice Research
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The aim of this elective course is to provide students with an advanced level of knowledge in biostatistics and to enable them to appropriately apply such knowledge for evaluating nursing innovation in the complex health care context. This course also enables the students to have an advanced level of statistical literacy to appraise the science in nursing and health care.

title: Applied Statistics for Evidence-based Practice
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing and Master of Nursing
description: The course aims to provide students with an advanced level of knowledge in statistics to enable them to appropriately apply such knowledge for evaluating nursing innovation in the complex healthcare context. It also enables the students to have an advanced level of statistical literacy to appraise the science in nursing and health care. The course covers regression modelling, psychometric evaluation methods, repeated measures, factors analysis, and structural equation modelling.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. develop the knowledge and skills to read, critically evaluate, and discuss the statistical methods in scientific nursing literature. 2. critically discuss the methods and considerations in identifying appropriate statistical methods for evaluating an evidence-based nursing practice. 3. develop the knowledge and skills in conducting a variety of statistical techniques for evaluating the effects of an evidence-based nursing practice. 4. develop the knowledge and skills in adopting a variety of statistical techniques to estimate sample size required for evaluating an evidence-based nursing practice.

title: Scholarly Inquiry Project
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course facilitates students to undertake a scholarly inquiry project for knowledge development and transfer. Students are required to complete a research or service innovation project, and are expected to integrate the knowledge that have been obtained from Scholarly Inquiry I & II into this project.

title: Scholarly Inquiry Project I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course facilitates students to develop a scholarly inquiry project in promoting evidence-based practice through knowledge development and transfer. Students are expected to utilise the research findings to meet the changing healthcare needs and to enhance the quality of care. They are required to apply the knowledge they have learned in this master’s programme to complete the scholarly inquiry project. In addition, reflection on the process of developing research methods or project plans, and the strategies adopted to overcome difficulties during the process will be shared and discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:1. discuss the existing nursing practice in a selected clinical setting.2. demonstrate critical thinking skills in appraising the relevant evidence to address the service/ knowledge gap. 3. initiate innovations through a research/ service innovation project approach to enhance advanced practice in a selected clinical setting.4. describe the research method/ project plan developed for their scholarly inquiry project, and present the innovative materials if applicable.5. identify the strengths and weaknesses of the selected research method/ innovative service.6. critically discuss the significant issues related to their own and their peers’ research methods/ project plans.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to equip students with fundamental and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students' understanding of the application of basic nursing care principles to safely help clients meet their basic needs of living.
outcome: At the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. Apply communication skills in dealing with individuals across their life span and members of the healthcare team. 2. Demonstrate essential nursing techniques like reporting and documentation skills.  3. Exhibit understanding and skills in helping clients meet their basic needs of living, including maintaining body temperature, promoting rest and sleep, and meeting activity and mobility needs. 4. Demonstrate ability to perform health assessment for individuals using a systematic approach.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to equip students with fundamental and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students' understanding of the application of basic principles of nursing care to safely help clients meet their basic needs of living. Drug administration skills will also be included.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. Discuss the nursing skills in helping clients to meet their basic needs of living including safety needs, promoting hygiene, bowel elimination needs, wound care, and pain relief. 2. Discuss the essential nursing skills including maintaining a safe and comfortable environment for care, and infection control. 3. Discuss the nursing skills in promoting the client’s sexual health. 4. Discuss the nursing skills in helping clients to meet their psychosocial and spiritual needs of hospitalization and cope with loss, grief, and death. 5. Describe nursing responsibilities in preparing and assisting the client to undertake diagnostic procedures.  6. Apply the basic principles of pharmacological interventions in clinical nursing practice.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing III

description: This course aims to equip students with fundamental and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students' understanding of the application of basic principles of nursing care to safely help clients meet their basic needs of living.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Apply principles and research findings from the biological, behavioural, and nursing sciences to meet clients’ basic needs of living, including respiratory, fluid and nutrition, and urinary elimination. 2. Demonstrate skills and knowledge in helping clients meet their respiratory, fluid and nutritional, and urinary elimination needs. 3. Discuss the screening and monitoring processes of children at risk for developmental problems. 4. Apply the basic principles of pharmacological interventions in clinical nursing practice.

title: Anatomy I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge of human topographical anatomy with emphasis on those aspects of special signifi cance in the nursing practice. The course will partially run concurrently with that of physiology. The syllabus will be integrated so that students will be able to correlate structure and function.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Understand the different cell and tissue types of the body. 2. Understand the importance of cell and tissue structures to their functions. 3. Be acquainted with the general organization of the organs in the body and how they organize to form a functional system. 4. Learn the importance of the structural relationship and arrangement in the clinical setting. 5. Describe both the macroscopic and microscopic structures of the organs, and relate them to the functions of the organs. 6. Learn the origin and development of the organs and the associated birth defects.
